title: Initiative debate centers on judge's role in Miss. budget
text:
Hearing on Miss. school funding initiatives focuses on whether judge would control budget 
THE ASSOCIATED PRESS Published: 8/18/15 12:46 pm EDT - Updated: 8/18/15 12:49 pm EDT 
TUPELO, Mississippi â€” People are debating whether a judge would control the state budget if Mississippi voters approve a school funding initiative in November. 
The Northeast Mississippi Daily Journal reports ( http://bit.ly/1NhlvXd ) that during a public hearing Monday in Tupelo, supporters outnumbered opponents of Initiative 42. 
The proposed constitutional amendment got on the ballot through citizens' petitions. Supporters say it's intended to force lawmakers to fully fund an education budget formula that has been shortchanged. It says people could sue the state if school funding falls short. 
The Republican-controlled Legislature put an alternative, Initiative 42-A, on the same ballot, saying it would not allow lawsuits. 
Madison attorney Russ Latino says Initiative 42 would hurt representative government by taking the Legislature out of the budget process. 
Oxford attorney Merrill Nordstrom says that's "simply not true." 
Information from: Northeast Mississippi Daily Journal, http://djournal.com
